title: Gel Electrophoresis & Restriction Enzymes
learningObjectives: Explain the physical principles underlying agarose gel electrophoresis, including why DNA migrates toward the anode and how the gel matrix separates fragments by size
Select the appropriate agarose concentration for a given DNA size range and predict relative migration distances
Describe how intercalating dyes (ethidium bromide, SYBR Safe) enable visualization of DNA and the safety considerations involved
Identify common Type II restriction enzymes, their palindromic recognition sequences, and whether they produce sticky or blunt ends
Distinguish between 5' sticky ends, 3' sticky ends, and blunt ends and explain the cloning implications of each
Predict the fragment sizes resulting from single and double restriction digests of a known DNA sequence
Perform a virtual restriction digest using Benchling and interpret the resulting gel banding pattern
Connect gel electrophoresis and restriction enzyme concepts to the Week 2 Gel Art Lab

sections.title: Introduction: Why Gel Electrophoresis Matters
sections.content:
The Most Fundamental Technique in Molecular Biology

If you walk into almost any molecular biology laboratory in the world, you will find a gel electrophoresis setup. This deceptively simple technique, running DNA through a slab of jelly-like material in an electric field, is the backbone of modern genetics, forensics, diagnostics, and biotechnology. It is the first hands-on technique most biology students learn, and it remains indispensable even in the age of next-generation sequencing and CRISPR.

At its heart, gel electrophoresis answers a straightforward question: what sizes of DNA fragments are present in my sample? Whether you are checking that a PCR amplification produced the expected product, verifying that a restriction enzyme digest cut your plasmid at the right sites, confirming that a cloning step inserted your gene correctly, or analyzing forensic DNA evidence, gel electrophoresis provides a quick, visual, and reliable answer.

The Basis of the Week 2 Gel Art Lab

In the HTGAA Week 2 lab, you will use gel electrophoresis not just as an analytical tool, but as a creative medium. The Gel Art Lab challenges you to digest plasmid DNA with various combinations of restriction enzymes and arrange the resulting banding patterns into artistic compositions on an agarose gel. To succeed, you need to understand two interconnected technologies: the restriction enzymes that cut DNA at specific sequences (creating fragments of predictable sizes) and the gel electrophoresis system that separates and displays those fragments.

These two techniques are deeply intertwined historically. Restriction enzymes were discovered in the late 1960s and early 1970s as part of research into how bacteria defend themselves against viral infection. Gel electrophoresis provided the critical tool for seeing the results of restriction enzyme digestion, confirming that specific enzymes cut DNA at specific sites. Together, they launched the recombinant DNA revolution that gave birth to modern biotechnology.

What You Will Learn

This topic guide covers the complete conceptual foundation you need for the Gel Art Lab and the Benchling virtual digest homework. You will learn:

  • The physics of gel electrophoresis: why DNA is negatively charged, how agarose creates a molecular sieve, and how fragment size determines migration speed
  • DNA visualization: how intercalating dyes make DNA visible, what DNA ladders are, and how to estimate fragment sizes from a gel image
  • Restriction enzymes: how they work, what palindromic recognition sequences are, and the key enzymes you will use in lab (EcoRI, HindIII, BamHI, KpnI, EcoRV, SacI, SalI)
  • Sticky vs. blunt ends: the molecular difference, why it matters for cloning, and which enzymes produce which type
  • Practical gel technique: casting, loading, running, and imaging a gel, plus common troubleshooting
  • Gel art and virtual digest: how to plan restriction digests for artistic effect and use Benchling to predict your results computationally

By the end, you should be able to look at a plasmid map, choose restriction enzymes, predict the banding pattern on a gel, and then create that pattern in the lab.

checkQuestion.question: What is the primary purpose of gel electrophoresis in molecular biology?
options: To amplify DNA using polymerase chain reaction
To separate DNA fragments by size so they can be visualized and analyzed
To sequence DNA by reading individual bases
To join DNA fragments together using ligase
checkQuestion.explanation: Gel electrophoresis separates DNA fragments by size using an electric field and an agarose gel matrix. Smaller fragments migrate faster through the gel pores. This allows researchers to determine the sizes and quantities of DNA fragments in a sample, making it essential for verifying digests, PCR products, and cloning results.

sections.title: The Physics of Gel Electrophoresis
sections.content:
DNA Carries a Uniform Negative Charge

The key physical property that makes gel electrophoresis work is the uniform negative charge of DNA. Every nucleotide in a DNA strand contributes one negatively charged phosphate group to the sugar-phosphate backbone. This means a 1,000 bp fragment has approximately 2,000 negative charges (one per nucleotide on each strand), while a 5,000 bp fragment has approximately 10,000 negative charges. The charge is directly proportional to the length of the molecule.

This proportionality has a critical consequence: the charge-to-mass ratio of DNA is essentially constant regardless of fragment size. A 500 bp fragment and a 5,000 bp fragment experience the same electrophoretic force per unit mass. If you placed DNA in an electric field with no gel matrix (free solution electrophoresis), all DNA fragments would migrate at the same speed, and you would get no separation at all. This is fundamentally different from protein electrophoresis, where proteins have varying charge-to-mass ratios based on their amino acid composition.

The Agarose Gel as a Molecular Sieve

The separation magic happens because of the agarose gel matrix. Agarose is a polysaccharide extracted from seaweed (red algae, specifically Gelidium and Gracilaria species). When dissolved in hot buffer and cooled, agarose forms a mesh of interconnected pores through hydrogen bonding between the polysaccharide chains. These pores create a molecular sieve: a three-dimensional obstacle course that DNA fragments must navigate.

Smaller DNA fragments can thread through the pores relatively easily, weaving through the gel matrix with less resistance. Larger fragments encounter more friction and must deform or reptate (snake) through the pore network, significantly slowing their progress. The result is size-dependent separation: smaller fragments reach the bottom of the gel first, while larger fragments lag behind near the top (closer to the wells where samples were loaded).

Deep dive: The physics of DNA migration through agarose gels involves two distinct regimes depending on fragment size. For smaller DNA molecules (roughly below 20 kb in a 1% gel), the migration follows the Ogston sieving model: the DNA threads through pores like a ball rolling through a mesh screen, and the migration rate depends on the ratio of the DNA's hydrodynamic radius to the average pore size. For very large DNA (above 20-50 kb), standard electrophoresis fails because the Ogston model breaks down — the DNA is too big to fit through any pore, yet it must still migrate. Instead, the DNA undergoes reptation (from the Latin for "creeping"): the long molecule deforms and snakes end-first through the gel matrix, driven by the electric field pulling the leading end forward. In reptation, migration becomes nearly size-independent because all large molecules reptate at similar speeds, which is why pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) is needed for separating very large DNA. PFGE works by periodically changing the direction of the electric field: each time the field direction changes, the DNA molecule must reorient, and larger molecules take longer to reorient than smaller ones, restoring size-dependent separation. This allows PFGE to separate DNA fragments from 50 kb up to 10 megabases, essential for bacterial genome mapping and karyotyping.

The Pore Size Is Controlled by Agarose Concentration

The average pore size in the gel is determined by the agarose concentration. Higher concentrations produce denser gels with smaller pores, which are better for separating small DNA fragments. Lower concentrations produce gels with larger pores, ideal for resolving large fragments. Choosing the right agarose concentration for your expected fragment sizes is one of the most important practical decisions in gel electrophoresis.

Here is the standard agarose concentration guide:

Agarose ConcentrationEffective Separation RangeBest For
0.5%1,000 - 30,000 bp (1-30 kb)Large genomic fragments, lambda DNA digests
0.8%800 - 12,000 bp (0.8-12 kb)General purpose, plasmid digests
1.0%400 - 8,000 bp (0.4-8 kb)Most common concentration; PCR products, plasmid digests
1.5%200 - 4,000 bp (0.2-4 kb)Smaller PCR products, fine resolution of mid-range fragments
2.0%100 - 2,000 bp (0.1-2 kb)Small fragments, restriction mapping of small regions

For the Gel Art Lab, a 1.0% agarose gel is typically used because it provides good resolution across the range of fragment sizes produced by most restriction enzyme digests of common plasmids (typically 500 bp to 10 kb).

The Logarithmic Relationship Between Size and Migration

Within the effective separation range, the migration distance is approximately proportional to the logarithm of the reciprocal of the fragment size. In mathematical terms:

Distance migrated is proportional to log(1/size)

This means that if you plot migration distance (y-axis) against the log of the fragment size (x-axis), you get a roughly linear relationship. This is the basis for how DNA ladders work: by running fragments of known size alongside your unknown samples, you can construct a standard curve and interpolate the sizes of your unknown bands.

An important practical consequence of this logarithmic relationship is that resolution decreases for larger fragments. Small fragments (say 200 bp vs. 300 bp) are well separated on a gel, but large fragments (say 9,000 bp vs. 10,000 bp) may run very close together and be difficult to distinguish. For very large DNA (above 20-50 kb), standard electrophoresis fails entirely, and specialized techniques like pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE) must be used. PFGE alternates the direction of the electric field at regular intervals, forcing large DNA molecules to reorient and thread through the gel, restoring size-dependent separation up to several megabases.

Voltage, Run Time, and Buffer

Three additional parameters affect gel electrophoresis results:

Voltage: Higher voltage drives DNA through the gel faster, reducing run time. However, excessive voltage generates heat, which can melt the agarose, distort bands, and even denature DNA. A typical setting is 5-10 volts per centimeter of gel length (measured between the electrodes). For a 10 cm gel, this means 50-100 V. Higher voltages (up to 150 V) can be used for short runs, but lower voltages (40-60 V) give better resolution for critical experiments.

Run time: Longer run times give better separation but risk running small fragments off the end of the gel. Most standard gels run for 30-60 minutes. The tracking dyes in the loading buffer (discussed in the next section) help you gauge when to stop: when the leading dye front has migrated about two-thirds to three-quarters of the gel length, it is usually time to stop.

Buffer: The gel is submerged in a conductive buffer that carries current and maintains pH. The two most common buffers are TAE (Tris-acetate-EDTA) and TBE (Tris-borate-EDTA). TAE is the most widely used general-purpose buffer and is preferred when DNA will be extracted from the gel afterward (because borate in TBE can inhibit downstream enzymatic reactions). TBE provides better buffering capacity and sharper bands for prolonged runs, making it the better choice for high-resolution separation of small fragments.

checkQuestion.question: Why does a 2.0% agarose gel resolve small DNA fragments better than a 0.5% gel?
options: Higher agarose concentration increases the voltage across the gel
Higher agarose concentration creates smaller pores that provide more sieving for small fragments
Higher agarose concentration makes DNA fluoresce more brightly
Higher agarose concentration denatures large DNA fragments so they do not interfere
checkQuestion.explanation: Increasing the agarose concentration produces a gel with smaller average pore sizes. Small DNA fragments (100-2000 bp) experience more differential resistance in these smaller pores, leading to better separation. A 0.5% gel has pores too large to effectively sieve small fragments, so they all run together near the bottom. Conversely, a 2.0% gel would impede large fragments so severely that they barely enter the gel.

sections.title: DNA Visualization
sections.content:
The Invisible Molecule: Making DNA Visible

DNA is colorless and invisible in an agarose gel. To see where your DNA fragments have migrated, you need a visualization method. The most common approach uses fluorescent intercalating dyes that bind to DNA and emit light when excited by the appropriate wavelength.

Ethidium Bromide: The Classic Dye

Ethidium bromide (EtBr) is the oldest and most well-known DNA visualization dye. It is a flat, planar molecule that intercalates (inserts itself) between the stacked base pairs of double-stranded DNA. When EtBr intercalates into DNA, its fluorescence increases approximately 20-fold compared to free EtBr in solution. Under ultraviolet (UV) light at 302 nm, EtBr-DNA complexes emit bright orange-red fluorescence at around 590 nm.

EtBr can be added directly to the molten agarose before casting (at approximately 0.5 micrograms per milliliter), or the gel can be soaked in an EtBr solution after running (post-staining). Pre-staining is more convenient, but EtBr in the gel slightly alters DNA migration because the intercalated dye changes the DNA's charge and stiffness. Post-staining avoids this but adds an extra step.

The major concern with ethidium bromide is its mutagenicity. Because EtBr intercalates into DNA, it can cause frameshift mutations by distorting the DNA helix during replication. Although the actual health risk from normal laboratory use is debated (EtBr is poorly absorbed through skin and is rapidly metabolized), most laboratories treat it as a potential carcinogen and require gloves, designated work areas, and special waste disposal procedures. EtBr waste must be decontaminated (typically with activated charcoal filtration) before disposal.

Behind the scenes: Ethidium bromide intercalates into DNA by sliding between the stacked base pairs, a process that unwinds the double helix by about 26 degrees per intercalated molecule. This unwinding is why EtBr affects DNA migration: intercalated DNA is less compact and has altered electrophoretic mobility. The fluorescence enhancement when EtBr binds DNA occurs because intercalation rigidifies the ethidium cation and reduces non-radiative energy loss. In free solution, EtBr molecules can rotate and vibrate freely, dissipating absorbed energy as heat; when locked between base pairs, these motions are restricted, so absorbed UV energy is instead emitted as fluorescence. Interestingly, SYBR dyes (SYBR Safe, SYBR Green) use a different mechanism: they are cyanine dyes that bind in the DNA minor groove rather than intercalating, which is why they cause less distortion of DNA structure and have lower mutagenicity. SYBR dyes also exhibit even greater fluorescence enhancement upon binding (up to 1000-fold for SYBR Green I), making them more sensitive than EtBr at lower dye concentrations. The blue-light excitation option for SYBR Safe (470 nm) is gentler than UV (302 nm), reducing DNA photodamage — critical when you need to gel-purify fragments for cloning, where nicked or damaged DNA reduces transformation efficiency.

Safer Alternatives: SYBR Safe and GelRed

Due to safety concerns about ethidium bromide, many laboratories have switched to alternative dyes. SYBR Safe (Invitrogen/Thermo Fisher) is the most popular alternative. It has been shown to be significantly less mutagenic than EtBr in Ames tests (a standard assay for mutagenicity). SYBR Safe can be visualized with either UV light or blue light (around 470 nm), and the blue light option is preferred because it avoids exposing DNA to damaging UV radiation, which is important if you plan to recover DNA from the gel for downstream applications like cloning.

GelRed (Biotium) is another popular alternative. It is a larger molecule that cannot penetrate cell membranes, making it effectively non-mutagenic to living cells. GelRed provides sensitivity comparable to EtBr and is visualized with standard UV transilluminators.

DNA Ladders: Your Molecular Ruler

To determine the size of DNA fragments on a gel, you need a reference standard. A DNA ladder (also called a molecular weight marker) is a mixture of DNA fragments of precisely known sizes. The ladder is loaded into one or more lanes of the gel alongside your experimental samples. After running, you compare the positions of your unknown bands to the ladder bands to estimate sizes.

The two most commonly used ladders are:

  • 1 kb DNA Ladder: Contains fragments ranging from approximately 500 bp to 10,000 bp (10 kb), with bands at regular intervals. Ideal for plasmid digests and PCR products in the 1-10 kb range.
  • 100 bp DNA Ladder: Contains fragments from 100 bp to 1,000-1,500 bp, with bands every 100 bp. Ideal for precise sizing of small PCR products and fine restriction fragments.

To estimate the size of an unknown fragment, you can construct a standard curve by plotting the log of the known fragment sizes against their migration distances. Then, measure the migration distance of your unknown band and read its size from the curve. In practice, many researchers estimate sizes by eye, comparing band positions to the nearest ladder bands.

Loading Dye and Tracking Dyes

Before loading DNA samples into the gel wells, they are mixed with loading dye (also called loading buffer). Loading dye serves three purposes:

  1. Density: It contains glycerol or Ficoll, which makes the sample denser than the surrounding buffer so it sinks into the well rather than floating away.
  2. Color tracking: It contains one or more colored dyes that migrate through the gel at predictable rates, allowing you to monitor the progress of electrophoresis without needing to visualize the DNA itself.
  3. Sample visualization: The color helps you see which wells you have already loaded, preventing double-loading or skipping a well.

The two most common tracking dyes are bromophenol blue (which migrates at approximately the same rate as a 300 bp fragment in a 1% gel) and xylene cyanol (which migrates at approximately the rate of a 4,000 bp fragment in a 1% gel). By watching these dye fronts, you can estimate how far your DNA fragments have run without stopping the gel.

Photography and Gel Documentation

After running, the gel is placed on a UV transilluminator or a blue-light transilluminator, which excites the fluorescent dye bound to DNA. The glowing bands are then photographed with a camera equipped with an appropriate filter (orange filter for EtBr, amber filter for SYBR Safe). Modern gel documentation systems (gel doc stations) integrate the light source, camera, and software for consistent, publication-quality images. Many systems can also perform basic analysis, such as measuring band intensity and estimating molecular weights.

For the Gel Art Lab, high-quality gel photography is essential because your artistic gel will be documented and shared. Adjusting exposure time, contrast, and the amount of DNA loaded per lane all affect the visual quality of your gel art.

checkQuestion.question: Why have many laboratories replaced ethidium bromide with SYBR Safe for DNA visualization?
options: SYBR Safe produces much brighter fluorescence than ethidium bromide
SYBR Safe is significantly less mutagenic and can be visualized with safer blue light instead of UV
Ethidium bromide does not work with agarose gels
SYBR Safe is much cheaper than ethidium bromide
checkQuestion.explanation: SYBR Safe has been shown to be significantly less mutagenic than ethidium bromide in standard mutagenicity assays (Ames test). Additionally, SYBR Safe can be excited by blue light (~470 nm) instead of UV light, which is safer for the user and causes less photodamage to DNA (important if you want to recover fragments for cloning). Sensitivity is comparable between the two dyes.

sections.title: Restriction Enzymes: Molecular Scissors
sections.content:
Bacterial Defense Against Phage

Restriction enzymes are one of nature's most elegant defense systems. Bacteria are under constant attack by bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria). To survive, bacteria evolved restriction-modification (R-M) systems: a paired set of enzymes where a restriction endonuclease recognizes and cuts foreign DNA at specific sequences, while a companion methyltransferase adds methyl groups to those same sequences in the bacterial genome, protecting it from cleavage.

When a phage injects its DNA into a bacterium, the restriction enzyme scans the foreign DNA for its recognition sequence. Finding unmodified (unmethylated) sites, it cleaves the phage DNA, destroying the invader. The bacterium's own DNA is spared because the methyltransferase has already added protective methyl groups to every occurrence of the recognition sequence in the host genome. This is a restriction-modification system: the bacterium restricts phage growth by destroying phage DNA, while modifying its own DNA for protection.

The discovery of restriction enzymes in the late 1960s and early 1970s by Werner Arber, Daniel Nathans, and Hamilton Smith earned them the 1978 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Their work laid the foundation for recombinant DNA technology and the entire biotechnology industry.

Type II Restriction Enzymes: The Laboratory Workhorse

There are several types of restriction enzymes (Types I, II, III, and IV), but Type II enzymes are by far the most useful for laboratory work. Type II enzymes are special because they:

  1. Recognize a specific, defined DNA sequence (typically 4-8 base pairs)
  2. Cut at a fixed position within or immediately adjacent to the recognition sequence
  3. Require only Mg2+ as a cofactor (no ATP needed)
  4. Function independently of the methyltransferase

This predictability is what makes Type II enzymes so powerful for molecular biology. Given a known DNA sequence, you can exactly predict where a Type II enzyme will cut and what fragments will result. Type I and Type III enzymes, in contrast, cut at variable or distant positions from their recognition sites, making them much less useful for precise DNA manipulation.

Palindromic Recognition Sequences

Most Type II restriction enzymes recognize palindromic sequences. In molecular biology, a palindrome is a sequence that reads the same on both strands when read in the 5' to 3' direction. For example, the EcoRI recognition sequence is:

5'-GAATTC-3'
3'-CTTAAG-5'

Read the top strand left to right: G-A-A-T-T-C. Now read the bottom strand left to right (which means right to left as shown): G-A-A-T-T-C. They are identical. This symmetry is not a coincidence: most Type II restriction enzymes function as homodimers (two identical protein subunits). Each subunit recognizes the same sequence on one strand, and the palindromic nature ensures that both subunits bind their respective strands in the same orientation.

The Essential Enzyme Table

Here are the seven restriction enzymes you will encounter in the Week 2 lab. Understanding each enzyme's recognition sequence, cut position, and end type is essential for planning your digests:

EnzymeRecognition & Cut SiteEnd TypeOverhangSource Organism
EcoRI5'-G^AATTC-3'
3'-CTTAA^G-5'		5' Sticky5'-AATT (4 nt)Escherichia coli RY13
HindIII5'-A^AGCTT-3'
3'-TTCGA^A-5'		5' Sticky5'-AGCT (4 nt)Haemophilus influenzae Rd
BamHI5'-G^GATCC-3'
3'-CCTAG^G-5'		5' Sticky5'-GATC (4 nt)Bacillus amyloliquefaciens H
KpnI5'-GGTAC^C-3'
3'-C^CATGG-5'		3' Sticky3'-GTAC (4 nt)Klebsiella pneumoniae OK8
EcoRV5'-GAT^ATC-3'
3'-CTA^TAG-5'		BluntNoneEscherichia coli J62 pLG74
SacI5'-GAGCT^C-3'
3'-C^TCGAG-5'		3' Sticky3'-AGCT (4 nt)Streptomyces achromogenes
SalI5'-G^TCGAC-3'
3'-CAGCT^G-5'		5' Sticky5'-TCGA (4 nt)Streptomyces albus G

Reading the Cut Site Notation

In the table above, the caret symbol (^) indicates where the enzyme cleaves each strand. For EcoRI, the top strand is cut between G and A (5'-G^AATTC-3'), while the bottom strand is cut between A and G (3'-CTTAA^G-5'). Because these cut positions are offset (staggered), the resulting fragments have single-stranded overhangs at their ends. For EcoRV, both strands are cut at the center (5'-GAT^ATC-3'), producing blunt ends with no overhang.

Frequency of Cut Sites

How often does a restriction enzyme cut? The expected frequency of a recognition site depends on its length, assuming random DNA sequence:

  • 4-base cutter (e.g., HaeIII, GGCC): cuts every 44 = 256 bp on average
  • 6-base cutter (e.g., EcoRI, GAATTC): cuts every 46 = 4,096 bp on average
  • 8-base cutter (e.g., NotI, GCGGCCGC): cuts every 48 = 65,536 bp on average

This means a typical 6-base cutter will cut a 5 kb plasmid approximately once, and a 48.5 kb lambda phage genome approximately 5-12 times (depending on GC content and sequence composition). Four-base cutters produce many small fragments, which is why they are called frequent cutters. Eight-base cutters produce very large fragments and are called rare cutters, useful for mapping large genomes.

Star Activity: When Enzymes Misbehave

Star activity refers to the relaxation of an enzyme's sequence specificity under non-optimal conditions, causing it to cut at sites similar to (but not exactly matching) its canonical recognition sequence. Star activity can be triggered by:

  • Excess glycerol (above 5% v/v in the reaction) — enzyme storage buffers contain 50% glycerol, so adding too much enzyme can push glycerol levels too high
  • Low ionic strength (incorrect or too-dilute buffer)
  • Non-optimal pH (typically too high)
  • Excess enzyme relative to DNA substrate (over-digestion)
  • Non-optimal divalent cations (Mn2+ instead of Mg2+)
  • Extended incubation beyond the recommended time

Star activity produces unexpected bands on a gel, which can be confusing and ruin an experiment. Modern high-fidelity (HF) restriction enzymes from suppliers like New England Biolabs have been engineered to minimize star activity, but it is still important to use the recommended buffer, enzyme amount, and incubation conditions.

Practical Tips for Restriction Digests

When setting up a restriction digest, follow these guidelines for best results:

  • Use the manufacturer's recommended buffer for each enzyme. If performing a double digest (two enzymes simultaneously), check compatibility using online tools like the NEB Double Digest Finder.
  • Use 5-10 units of enzyme per microgram of DNA for a 1-hour digest at 37 degrees C. One unit is defined as the amount of enzyme needed to completely digest 1 microgram of lambda DNA in 1 hour.
  • Keep the total glycerol concentration below 5% (typically means enzyme volume should be less than 10% of the total reaction volume).
  • Include a positive control (a DNA substrate with known sites) and a negative control (uncut DNA) to verify the digest worked correctly.

checkQuestion.question: A 6-base cutter like EcoRI is expected to cut randomly sequenced DNA on average every how many base pairs?
checkQuestion.explanation: For a 6-base recognition sequence, assuming each position has an equal probability (1/4) of being the required base, the expected frequency is 4^6 = 4,096 bp. This means a 6-base cutter will, on average, find its recognition site once every ~4,096 bp of random DNA. Of course, actual genomes are not random, so the real frequency varies with sequence composition and GC content.

sections.title: Sticky vs. Blunt Ends
sections.content:
Two Types of DNA Ends

When a restriction enzyme cuts double-stranded DNA, it can produce one of two types of ends: sticky ends (also called cohesive ends) or blunt ends. The type of end depends on whether the enzyme cuts the two strands at staggered positions (sticky) or at the same position (blunt). Understanding the difference is critical for cloning, because the end type determines how DNA fragments can be joined together.

Sticky Ends: Built-in Velcro

Sticky ends are short single-stranded overhangs (typically 2-4 nucleotides) left after staggered cutting. These overhangs are complementary to the overhangs produced by the same enzyme at any other site. For example, every EcoRI cut produces the same 5'-AATT overhang on both fragment ends. When two EcoRI-cut fragments come together, the complementary AATT overhangs can base-pair by Watson-Crick hydrogen bonding, temporarily holding the fragments together. DNA ligase then seals the phosphodiester backbone covalently, creating a permanent join.

Sticky ends come in two flavors:

  • 5' overhangs (5' sticky ends): The top strand extends beyond the bottom strand at the 5' end. Produced by enzymes like EcoRI, HindIII, BamHI, and SalI. These are the most common type.
  • 3' overhangs (3' sticky ends): The bottom strand extends beyond the top strand, leaving a recessed 5' end. Produced by enzymes like KpnI, SacI, and PstI. These are less common and can be harder to work with in certain applications (e.g., they are less efficient substrates for end-labeling with Klenow fragment).

The major advantage of sticky ends for cloning is efficiency. The complementary overhangs dramatically increase the effective concentration of properly aligned ends, making ligation 10-100 times more efficient than blunt-end ligation. Additionally, sticky ends provide directionality: a fragment cut with EcoRI on one end and BamHI on the other can only insert into a vector cut with the same two enzymes in one orientation, because the EcoRI end can only ligate to another EcoRI end, and the BamHI end can only ligate to another BamHI end.

Blunt Ends: Universal but Inefficient

Blunt ends have no single-stranded overhang; both strands terminate at the same position. Enzymes like EcoRV (GAT^ATC) and SmaI (CCC^GGG) produce blunt ends. The advantage of blunt ends is universality: any blunt end can be ligated to any other blunt end, regardless of which enzyme produced it. This gives maximum flexibility in cloning design.

The disadvantage is dramatically lower ligation efficiency. Without complementary overhangs to hold fragments together, blunt-end ligation relies on random collision and transient alignment of the two DNA ends in the ligase active site. Typical blunt-end ligation efficiency is 10-100 times lower than sticky-end ligation. Higher concentrations of DNA ligase, longer incubation times, and additives like polyethylene glycol (PEG, which serves as a molecular crowding agent) can improve blunt-end ligation, but it remains less efficient than sticky-end ligation.

Another consideration is that blunt-end ligation provides no directional control. A blunt-ended insert can ligate into a blunt-ended vector in either orientation (forward or reverse), so approximately half of all clones will have the insert in the wrong direction. This must be screened for after transformation.

Compatible Ends from Different Enzymes

An important and sometimes surprising concept is that different restriction enzymes can produce compatible (complementary) sticky ends. For example:

  • BamHI (5'-G^GATCC-3') produces a 5'-GATC overhang
  • BglII (5'-A^GATCT-3') also produces a 5'-GATC overhang
  • MboI (5'-^GATC-3') produces the same 5'-GATC overhang

Because all three enzymes produce the same 4-nucleotide 5' overhang (GATC), a BamHI-cut end can base-pair with and be ligated to a BglII-cut end or an MboI-cut end. However, the resulting hybrid site (e.g., G-GATCT from BamHI + BglII) is no longer recognized by either original enzyme. This is useful in cloning strategies where you want to prevent re-cutting of the ligation product.

Similarly, SalI (5'-G^TCGAC-3') and XhoI (5'-C^TCGAG-3') both produce 4-nucleotide 5' overhangs (TCGA), making them compatible. This compatibility expands the number of cloning strategies available to molecular biologists.

Practical Cloning Implications

When designing a cloning experiment, the choice of restriction enzymes directly affects your strategy:

  • Directional cloning: Use two different sticky-end enzymes (e.g., EcoRI + BamHI) to force the insert into the vector in only one orientation.
  • Maximum flexibility: Use blunt-end enzymes and accept the lower efficiency and need to screen orientations.
  • Destroying cut sites: Use compatible enzymes from different families (e.g., BamHI + BglII) so the ligated junction cannot be re-cut.
  • Gel Art Lab: The enzyme choice determines the number and size of fragments, which directly controls the banding pattern on your gel. More cut sites means more bands and smaller fragments.

checkQuestion.question: Why are sticky-end ligations much more efficient than blunt-end ligations?
options: Sticky ends contain more phosphate groups for ligase to act on
Blunt ends are degraded by nucleases in the ligation reaction
The complementary single-stranded overhangs base-pair, holding fragments together and increasing the effective concentration of properly aligned ends
Sticky-end ligations use a different, more active form of DNA ligase
checkQuestion.explanation: Sticky ends have short complementary single-stranded overhangs that can base-pair via Watson-Crick hydrogen bonding. This transient base-pairing holds the two DNA ends together in the correct alignment, dramatically increasing the probability that ligase will seal the backbone. Blunt ends lack this complementary pairing and must rely on random collision, making ligation 10-100 times less efficient.

sections.title: Running a Gel: Step-by-Step
sections.content:
Overview of the Gel Electrophoresis Workflow

Running a gel is a multi-step process that, once mastered, becomes almost second nature. The entire procedure, from casting the gel to photographing the results, typically takes 1.5 to 2.5 hours. Here is a detailed walkthrough of each step, including the common pitfalls and how to avoid them.

Step 1: Casting the Gel

Begin by preparing the agarose solution. Weigh out the appropriate amount of agarose powder for your desired concentration (e.g., 1.0 g of agarose in 100 mL of buffer for a 1% gel). Add the agarose to the buffer (TAE or TBE) in an Erlenmeyer flask. Microwave or heat the mixture in short intervals (30-60 seconds), swirling between intervals, until the agarose is completely dissolved and the solution is clear with no visible particles. Be careful: superheated agarose can boil over violently.

Allow the solution to cool to approximately 55-60 degrees C (warm but comfortable to touch the outside of the flask). If using a pre-stain dye like ethidium bromide or SYBR Safe, add it now and swirl gently to mix. Pour the molten agarose into the gel casting tray, which has been sealed at both ends with tape or removable dams. Insert the comb at one end to create the sample wells. The comb should not touch the bottom of the tray; a gap of about 1-2 mm ensures the wells have a bottom.

Allow the gel to solidify at room temperature for 20-30 minutes. The gel will become opaque and firm when set. Carefully remove the comb by pulling it straight up slowly (pulling at an angle can tear the wells). Remove the dams or tape from the ends of the casting tray.

Step 2: Loading the Samples

Place the gel (still in its casting tray) into the electrophoresis chamber and fill the chamber with running buffer (the same TAE or TBE used to make the gel) until the buffer covers the gel by approximately 2-3 mm. The wells should be at the negative electrode (cathode) end, because DNA is negatively charged and will migrate toward the positive electrode (anode) at the opposite end.

Prepare your DNA samples by mixing them with loading dye. A typical ratio is 1 part loading dye to 5 parts DNA sample. The loading dye adds density (so the sample sinks into the well) and color (so you can see the sample and track its migration). Using a micropipette with a fine tip, carefully pipette each sample into a well. Insert the pipette tip just above the well opening (do not push it into the well, which can puncture the bottom) and dispense slowly and steadily. Load the DNA ladder into at least one lane (often the first and/or last lane) for size reference.

Step 3: Running the Gel

Place the lid on the electrophoresis chamber, connecting the electrodes. Remember: "Run to red" is a common mnemonic, meaning DNA (negative) runs toward the red (positive) electrode. Set the power supply to the appropriate voltage (typically 80-120 V for a standard mini-gel). You should see small bubbles forming at both electrodes when current is flowing, confirming that the circuit is complete.

Monitor the migration of the tracking dyes. Bromophenol blue (the darker blue/purple dye) runs ahead and migrates at roughly the rate of a 300 bp fragment in a 1% gel. Xylene cyanol (the lighter blue/teal dye) runs slower, at roughly the rate of a 4,000 bp fragment in a 1% gel. Stop the gel when the bromophenol blue front has migrated approximately two-thirds to three-quarters of the gel length. Running too long risks losing small fragments off the end of the gel; not running long enough results in poor separation.

Step 4: Imaging the Gel

Carefully remove the gel from the electrophoresis chamber and place it on a UV transilluminator (for ethidium bromide or GelRed) or a blue-light transilluminator (for SYBR Safe). If using UV, wear UV-protective goggles or a face shield to protect your eyes. Turn on the light source, and the DNA bands will fluoresce. Photograph the gel using the documentation system, adjusting exposure time to get clear, well-defined bands without overexposure (which can cause bands to blur together).

Troubleshooting Common Problems

Even experienced researchers encounter gel problems. Here are the most common issues and their solutions:

  • Smeared bands (smearing): This can indicate DNA degradation (use fresh DNA and keep samples on ice), overloading (reduce the amount of DNA per lane), or running the gel at too high a voltage (reduce voltage to 5 V/cm). Nuclease contamination in your DNA preparation is a common cause of smearing.
  • No bands visible: Check that the DNA stain was added (a surprisingly common oversight). Verify that DNA is actually present in your sample (run a positive control). Ensure the transilluminator is working and the correct wavelength is selected. If post-staining, ensure the gel was soaked long enough (15-30 minutes).
  • Bands are faint: Increase the amount of DNA loaded (50-200 ng per band is typically needed for EtBr visualization). Increase exposure time when photographing. Consider using a more sensitive dye or post-staining to increase signal.
  • Unexpected bands: Check for star activity (enzyme cutting at non-canonical sites due to suboptimal conditions). Verify that your DNA is the correct substrate. Contamination with other DNA molecules can also produce unexpected bands. Undigested supercoiled plasmid DNA can appear as an extra band because supercoiled, relaxed circular, and linear forms of the same plasmid migrate differently.
  • Bands are curved or "smiling": This typically results from uneven heating caused by running at too high a voltage. The center of the gel heats up more than the edges, causing DNA in the middle lanes to migrate faster (creating a "smile" pattern). Reduce the voltage or use a gel running apparatus with better buffer circulation.
  • Wells are torn or jagged: The comb was removed too quickly or at an angle. Always pull the comb straight up slowly. Using a small amount of running buffer to lubricate the wells before removing the comb can help.

Try it: You run a gel and see a smear instead of discrete bands in all your digest lanes. The DNA ladder looks perfect. List at least three possible causes and how you would systematically troubleshoot each one. (Hints to consider: When did degradation occur — during the digest or before? Was the restriction enzyme contaminated with nuclease? Did you leave the digest at 37°C too long? Were the samples left at room temperature instead of on ice? Is there nuclease in your gel or running buffer?) For each hypothesis, describe a test: what control or variation would you run to confirm or rule out that cause? This troubleshooting exercise mimics real lab problem-solving.

Think about it: Why do supercoiled, relaxed circular, and linear forms of the same plasmid migrate at different speeds on a gel, even though they have the same number of base pairs? (Hint: Consider the three-dimensional structure and compactness of each form. Supercoiled DNA is highly compact and tightly wound, relaxed circular is open but still circular, and linear is a straight rod. Which conformation encounters the most friction in the gel matrix?) In a typical uncut plasmid prep, you often see multiple bands even from a "pure" plasmid sample: the fastest-migrating band is supercoiled (most compact), the slowest is relaxed circular (least compact), and linear (if present from nicking) migrates in between. Understanding DNA topology is essential for interpreting plasmid prep gels and verifying successful restriction digests, which convert all forms to linear.

checkQuestion.question: You run a gel and notice that all lanes show smeared DNA rather than distinct bands. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
options: The agarose concentration was too high
The DNA samples were degraded by nuclease contamination
The gel was run backward (reversed polarity)
The DNA ladder was expired
checkQuestion.explanation: Smeared DNA (a continuous streak rather than discrete bands) is the hallmark of degraded DNA. Nuclease contamination in the DNA sample or preparation reagents is the most common cause. Nucleases randomly cut DNA into fragments of all sizes, producing a continuous smear rather than the discrete bands expected from a specific restriction digest. Other causes include overloading or excessive voltage, but degradation is the most common culprit.

sections.title: Gel Art & Virtual Digest
sections.content:
The Gel Art Lab: Science Meets Creativity

The Week 2 Gel Art Lab is one of the most memorable experiences in HTGAA. The concept is simple but delightful: instead of running a gel purely for analytical purposes, you design restriction enzyme digests to produce specific banding patterns that, when run side by side on a gel, create an artistic image or pattern. The glowing bands of DNA, fluorescing under UV or blue light against the dark background, produce images that are both scientifically informative and visually striking.

To create compelling gel art, you need to control several variables:

  • Choice of enzymes: Different restriction enzymes cut the same DNA substrate at different positions, producing different numbers and sizes of fragments. A single-enzyme digest might produce 2-5 bands, while a double digest (two enzymes simultaneously) can produce many more bands as each enzyme's sites generate additional fragments.
  • Number of cuts: More restriction sites in the DNA substrate means more fragments and more bands on the gel. A plasmid with one EcoRI site produces one band (the linearized plasmid), while one with three EcoRI sites produces three bands.
  • DNA amount per lane: The brightness of each band is proportional to the mass of DNA in that band. Loading more total DNA per lane makes all bands brighter. Lanes with very little DNA will appear dim.
  • Lane spacing and arrangement: The physical arrangement of which digest goes in which lane determines the overall visual pattern. Planning your lane order is essential for the artistic composition.

Virtual Digest with Benchling

Benchling is a cloud-based molecular biology platform widely used in academic and industrial labs. For the Week 2 homework, you will use Benchling to perform virtual restriction digests: computationally predicting where restriction enzymes will cut a given DNA sequence and what fragment sizes will result, without touching any physical reagent.

In Benchling, you can:

  1. Import or paste a DNA sequence (such as a plasmid map)
  2. Select restriction enzymes from a comprehensive database
  3. View the cut sites marked on the circular or linear map
  4. Generate a virtual gel image showing the predicted banding pattern
  5. Perform double digests by selecting two enzymes simultaneously

The virtual digest is an essential planning step before the actual lab. It tells you exactly what bands to expect, allowing you to design your gel art with confidence. If the predicted pattern does not match your artistic vision, you can try different enzyme combinations computationally until you find the pattern you want, saving time and reagents.

Single vs. Double Digests

A single digest uses one restriction enzyme. The number of fragments equals the number of cut sites in the DNA. For a circular plasmid, if the enzyme has n recognition sites, the digest produces n linear fragments. For linear DNA, n cut sites produce n + 1 fragments.

A double digest uses two restriction enzymes simultaneously (or sequentially, if the enzymes require different buffers). The total number of fragments is the sum of the individual cut sites. If enzyme A has 2 sites and enzyme B has 3 sites, a double digest of a circular plasmid produces 2 + 3 = 5 fragments. Double digests are frequently used in cloning to excise an insert from a vector (cutting once on each side of the insert with different enzymes), and in gel art to create more complex banding patterns.

When planning double digests, always verify that the two enzymes are compatible in the same buffer. Many enzyme suppliers (NEB, Thermo Fisher) provide online tools that show which enzyme pairs work well together in a single reaction buffer. If the enzymes require different buffers, you must perform sequential digests: digest with one enzyme, purify the DNA, then digest with the second enzyme. This is more laborious but sometimes necessary.

Connection to the Homework

The Gel Art Lab and Benchling virtual digest are directly connected to Parts 0, 1, and 2 of the Week 2 homework. In Part 0, you review the fundamentals of gel electrophoresis. In Part 1, you use Benchling to plan and perform virtual digests, predicting banding patterns computationally. In Part 2, you bring those plans into the lab, performing the actual restriction digests, running the gel, and creating your gel art masterpiece. The better your virtual planning, the better your gel art will turn out.

Remember: gel art is an iterative process. Your first attempt may not look exactly as planned, because subtle differences in DNA concentration, enzyme activity, and gel running conditions all affect the final image. But with careful planning and execution, you can create striking images that showcase both your scientific understanding and your creativity.

checkQuestion.question: A circular plasmid has 2 EcoRI sites and 3 BamHI sites. How many fragments will a double digest with both enzymes produce?
options: 2 fragments
3 fragments
5 fragments
6 fragments
checkQuestion.explanation: For a circular DNA molecule, a double digest produces a number of fragments equal to the total number of cut sites from both enzymes combined. With 2 EcoRI sites and 3 BamHI sites, there are 5 total cuts, producing 5 linear fragments. This is because each cut opens up an additional fragment from the circular molecule.

keyFacts.label: DNA Charge
keyFacts.value: DNA carries a uniform negative charge from its phosphate backbone, giving it a constant charge-to-mass ratio regardless of fragment size

keyFacts.label: Separation Principle
keyFacts.value: Agarose gel acts as a molecular sieve; smaller fragments migrate faster through the pores, separating DNA by size

keyFacts.label: 1% Agarose Range
keyFacts.value: A 1.0% agarose gel effectively separates DNA fragments from approximately 400 bp to 8,000 bp (0.4-8 kb)

keyFacts.label: 6-Base Cutter Frequency
keyFacts.value: A restriction enzyme with a 6-bp recognition site cuts randomly sequenced DNA on average every 4,096 bp (4^6)

keyFacts.label: EcoRI Produces 5' Sticky Ends
keyFacts.value: EcoRI cuts 5'-G^AATTC-3' to produce 4-nucleotide 5' overhangs (AATT), the most commonly used sticky ends in cloning

keyFacts.label: EcoRV Produces Blunt Ends
keyFacts.value: EcoRV cuts 5'-GAT^ATC-3' at the center of its palindrome, producing blunt ends with no overhang

keyFacts.label: Nobel Prize
keyFacts.value: Werner Arber, Daniel Nathans, and Hamilton Smith won the 1978 Nobel Prize for the discovery and application of restriction enzymes

keyFacts.label: Sticky > Blunt Ligation
keyFacts.value: Sticky-end ligation is 10-100 times more efficient than blunt-end ligation because complementary overhangs hold fragments in alignment

keyFacts.label: Run to Red
keyFacts.value: DNA migrates from cathode (-) to anode (+); the mnemonic 'Run to Red' reminds you that DNA runs toward the red (positive) electrode

keyFacts.label: EtBr Fluorescence
keyFacts.value: Ethidium bromide intercalates between DNA base pairs and fluoresces ~20-fold brighter when bound to DNA under UV light at 302 nm

vocabulary.definition: A technique for separating DNA (or RNA) fragments by size. An agarose gel matrix acts as a molecular sieve; when an electric field is applied, negatively charged nucleic acids migrate toward the positive electrode, with smaller fragments moving faster through the pores.

A bacterial enzyme that recognizes a specific DNA sequence (restriction site) and cleaves the phosphodiester backbone at defined positions. Part of the restriction-modification system that defends bacteria against bacteriophage DNA.

A DNA sequence that reads the same on both strands in the 5' to 3' direction. Example: EcoRI's recognition site 5'-GAATTC-3' is palindromic because the complementary strand also reads 5'-GAATTC-3'. Most Type II restriction enzymes recognize palindromic sequences.

Short single-stranded DNA overhangs (2-4 nucleotides, either 5' or 3') produced when a restriction enzyme cuts the two strands at staggered positions. Compatible sticky ends can base-pair and be ligated together efficiently.

DNA ends with no single-stranded overhang, produced when a restriction enzyme cuts both strands at the same position within the recognition site. Any blunt end can ligate to any other blunt end, but efficiency is much lower than sticky-end ligation.

A mixture of DNA fragments of precisely known sizes used as a reference standard in gel electrophoresis. Common types include the 1 kb ladder (500 bp to 10 kb) and the 100 bp ladder (100 bp to 1,500 bp).

A fluorescent intercalating dye that inserts between DNA base pairs and fluoresces orange-red under UV light. Widely used for DNA visualization in gels but is a mutagen; safer alternatives include SYBR Safe and GelRed.

The insertion of a flat, planar molecule between the stacked base pairs of double-stranded DNA. Intercalating dyes like ethidium bromide slide into the space between bases, which unwinds the helix slightly and dramatically increases the dye's fluorescence.

The relaxation of a restriction enzyme's sequence specificity under non-optimal conditions (excess glycerol, wrong buffer, too much enzyme, extended incubation), causing it to cut at sites that are similar to but not exactly its canonical recognition sequence.

A paired bacterial defense system consisting of a restriction endonuclease (which cuts foreign DNA at specific sequences) and a methyltransferase (which adds methyl groups to those same sequences in the host DNA, protecting it from cleavage).

The most commonly used class of restriction enzymes in molecular biology. They recognize specific palindromic sequences (typically 4-8 bp), cut at defined positions within or adjacent to the recognition site, and require only Mg2+ as a cofactor.

A solution mixed with DNA samples before gel loading that contains a dense agent (glycerol or Ficoll) to help samples sink into wells, and colored tracking dyes (bromophenol blue, xylene cyanol) to monitor electrophoresis progress.

A specialized electrophoresis technique that alternates the direction of the electric field at regular intervals, enabling separation of very large DNA molecules (50 kb to several megabases) that cannot be resolved by standard gel electrophoresis.

A restriction digest using two different enzymes simultaneously (or sequentially) on the same DNA substrate. The total number of fragments from a circular molecule equals the sum of cut sites from both enzymes.

quizQuestions.question: Why does DNA migrate toward the positive electrode (anode) during gel electrophoresis?
options: DNA has a net positive charge due to its amino groups
The agarose gel attracts DNA molecules chemically toward the anode
DNA has a net negative charge due to its phosphate backbone, and is attracted to the positive electrode
The electric field causes DNA to denature and move randomly toward the nearest electrode
quizQuestions.explanation: Each nucleotide in DNA contributes a negatively charged phosphate group to the sugar-phosphate backbone. This gives DNA a uniform negative charge. In an electric field, negatively charged molecules are attracted to the positive electrode (anode), so DNA migrates from the cathode (negative) toward the anode (positive).

quizQuestions.question: What is the difference between the products of EcoRI and EcoRV digestion?
options: EcoRI produces blunt ends; EcoRV produces sticky ends
EcoRI produces 4-nucleotide 5' sticky ends; EcoRV produces blunt ends
Both produce identical 4-nucleotide 5' overhangs but at different sequences
EcoRI cuts single-stranded DNA; EcoRV cuts double-stranded DNA
quizQuestions.explanation: EcoRI cuts 5'-G^AATTC-3' at staggered positions, producing 4-nucleotide 5' overhangs (5'-AATT sticky ends). EcoRV cuts 5'-GAT^ATC-3' at the exact center of its palindrome, cutting both strands at the same position and producing blunt ends with no overhang.

quizQuestions.question: A researcher needs to separate DNA fragments ranging from 100 bp to 1,500 bp with high resolution. Which agarose concentration is most appropriate?
options: 0.5% agarose
0.8% agarose
2.0% agarose
0.3% agarose
quizQuestions.explanation: A 2.0% agarose gel has small pores that provide excellent sieving for small DNA fragments in the 100-2,000 bp range. A 0.5% gel has pores too large to resolve fragments this small; they would all run to the bottom of the gel together. The 2.0% concentration offers the best resolution for the specified range.

quizQuestions.question: Why are restriction enzyme recognition sites typically palindromic?
options: Palindromic sequences are more common in bacterial genomes
The enzyme binds as a homodimer, with each identical subunit recognizing the same sequence on opposite strands
Palindromic sequences are easier to methylate for protection
Non-palindromic sequences cannot be cleaved by nucleases
quizQuestions.explanation: Most Type II restriction enzymes function as homodimers: two identical protein subunits that each recognize and bind the same DNA sequence. A palindromic recognition site ensures that both subunits see the same sequence on their respective strands (reading 5' to 3'), enabling symmetric binding and coordinated cleavage of both strands.

quizQuestions.question: What causes star activity in restriction enzymes?
options: Using too little enzyme relative to the DNA substrate
Running the gel at too high a voltage
Conditions like excess glycerol, wrong buffer, or extended incubation that relax the enzyme's sequence specificity
Using enzymes past their expiration date
quizQuestions.explanation: Star activity occurs when non-optimal reaction conditions cause a restriction enzyme to cut at sequences similar to, but not exactly matching, its canonical recognition site. Common triggers include excess glycerol (>5%), low ionic strength, wrong pH, too much enzyme, non-optimal metal ions (Mn2+ instead of Mg2+), and overly long incubation. Modern high-fidelity (HF) enzymes have been engineered to resist star activity.

quizQuestions.question: BamHI produces a 5'-GATC overhang and BglII also produces a 5'-GATC overhang. What is significant about this?
options: BamHI and BglII are the same enzyme with different names
Their compatible sticky ends can base-pair and be ligated, but the resulting hybrid site is not cut by either enzyme
They cannot be used in the same experiment because they would interfere with each other
Only BamHI ends can be ligated; BglII ends are non-functional
quizQuestions.explanation: BamHI (G^GATCC) and BglII (A^GATCT) produce identical 5'-GATC overhangs, making their ends compatible for ligation. However, the hybrid junction (GGATCT or AGATCC) is not recognized by either enzyme, which is useful in cloning when you want to prevent re-cutting of the ligated product.

quizQuestions.question: What is the function of the tracking dyes (bromophenol blue and xylene cyanol) in gel loading buffer?
options: They bind to DNA and make it visible under UV light
They stain the agarose gel for better photography
They migrate through the gel at predictable rates, allowing you to monitor electrophoresis progress without visualizing DNA
They protect DNA from degradation during electrophoresis
quizQuestions.explanation: Tracking dyes are small colored molecules that migrate through the gel at rates similar to DNA fragments of specific sizes. Bromophenol blue migrates like ~300 bp DNA in a 1% gel; xylene cyanol migrates like ~4,000 bp DNA. By watching these dye fronts, you can estimate how far your DNA has migrated without needing to stop the gel and visualize the DNA.

quizQuestions.question: How does ethidium bromide make DNA visible in a gel?
options: It covalently bonds to the phosphate backbone and absorbs visible light
It intercalates between base pairs, and the resulting complex fluoresces intensely under UV light
It causes DNA to precipitate and form visible aggregates in the gel
It catalyzes a chemical reaction that produces a colored precipitate along the DNA bands
quizQuestions.explanation: Ethidium bromide is a flat, planar molecule that intercalates (slides in) between the stacked base pairs of double-stranded DNA. When intercalated into DNA, EtBr's fluorescence increases approximately 20-fold compared to free EtBr in solution. Under UV excitation (~302 nm), the EtBr-DNA complex emits bright orange-red fluorescence (~590 nm), making the DNA bands visible.

quizQuestions.question: A circular plasmid has 3 HindIII sites and 2 SalI sites. How many fragments result from a double digest with both enzymes?
options: 3 fragments
4 fragments
5 fragments
6 fragments
quizQuestions.explanation: For a circular DNA molecule, a double digest produces fragments equal to the total number of cut sites. With 3 HindIII sites and 2 SalI sites, there are 5 total cuts around the circular plasmid, producing 5 linear fragments. Each cut opens up an additional fragment from the ring.

quizQuestions.question: Why is TAE buffer generally preferred over TBE when DNA will be extracted from the gel for cloning?
options: TAE provides higher resolution separation of DNA fragments
TBE buffer degrades DNA during electrophoresis
Borate in TBE can inhibit downstream enzymatic reactions like ligation and transformation
TAE buffer costs less than TBE buffer
quizQuestions.explanation: TBE (Tris-borate-EDTA) contains borate, which can form complexes with the cis-diol groups of sugar molecules in DNA and can inhibit enzymatic reactions used downstream, such as ligation and restriction digestion. TAE (Tris-acetate-EDTA) does not have this issue, making it the preferred buffer when DNA will be extracted from the gel for further manipulation.

quizQuestions.question: Match each restriction enzyme with its properties:
quizQuestions.explanation: EcoRI, BamHI, and HindIII all produce 5' sticky ends (overhangs on the 5' side). KpnI is notable for producing 3' sticky ends. EcoRV is the classic blunt-end cutter, cleaving at the center of its palindrome.

quizQuestions.question: Order the steps of running a gel electrophoresis experiment from first to last:
items: Pour molten agarose into casting tray with comb inserted
Prepare DNA samples by mixing with loading buffer
Load samples into wells after gel solidifies and is submerged in buffer
Apply voltage (5-10 V/cm) and run until tracking dye reaches 2/3 of gel
Visualize DNA bands under UV light (with intercalating dye)
Compare band positions to DNA ladder to determine fragment sizes
quizQuestions.explanation: First cast the gel, then prepare samples with loading buffer, load into wells, run the gel with electric current, visualize under UV, and finally analyze band sizes using the ladder as reference.

quizQuestions.question: What is the primary physical property that allows gel electrophoresis to separate DNA fragments?
options: DNA fragments have different densities based on their sequence
Smaller DNA fragments migrate faster through the gel pores due to size-dependent resistance
DNA fragments have different colors that can be sorted
Larger DNA fragments have more negative charge and migrate faster
quizQuestions.explanation: DNA has a uniform charge-to-mass ratio regardless of size. Separation occurs because smaller fragments navigate through the agarose pore network more easily than larger fragments, which experience more friction and migrate more slowly.

quizQuestions.question: A 4-base cutter restriction enzyme cuts DNA on average every how many base pairs?
quizQuestions.explanation: For a 4-base recognition sequence, assuming each position has a 1/4 probability of being the required base, the expected frequency is 4^4 = 256 bp. Four-base cutters are frequent cutters, producing many small fragments.

quizQuestions.question: Why does EcoRI produce compatible ends with BamHI-cut DNA that can be ligated together?
options: They do not produce compatible ends; this is incorrect
Both produce the same 5'-GATC overhang
Both produce blunt ends
Both recognize the same palindromic sequence
quizQuestions.explanation: EcoRI produces a 5'-AATT overhang while BamHI produces a 5'-GATC overhang. These are NOT compatible. However, BamHI IS compatible with BglII (both produce 5'-GATC). EcoRI is compatible with enzymes like MfeI that also produce AATT overhangs.

quizQuestions.question: What causes 'star activity' in restriction enzyme digests?
options: Using too little enzyme
Optimal pH and temperature conditions
Non-optimal conditions like excess glycerol, wrong buffer, or extended incubation
Adding too much DNA substrate
quizQuestions.explanation: Star activity occurs when suboptimal reaction conditions relax the enzyme's sequence specificity, causing it to cut at sites similar to but not exactly matching its recognition sequence. Common triggers include excess glycerol (>5%), low ionic strength, wrong pH, and over-digestion.

quizQuestions.question: Which type of DNA ends provides directional cloning control?
options: Blunt ends, because they are most stable
Two different sticky ends (e.g., EcoRI on one side, BamHI on the other)
5' overhangs only
3' overhangs only
quizQuestions.explanation: Using two different restriction enzymes that produce incompatible sticky ends (like EcoRI and BamHI) ensures the insert can only ligate into the vector in one orientation, because the EcoRI end can only join to another EcoRI end, and BamHI to BamHI.

quizQuestions.question: A DNA ladder shows bands at 1000 bp, 2000 bp, 3000 bp, etc. Your unknown sample runs between the 2000 bp and 3000 bp bands, closer to 2000 bp. What is the approximate size?
options: 500 bp
quizQuestions.explanation: If the unknown band runs between 2000 bp and 3000 bp, closer to the 2000 bp marker, its size is approximately 2200-2400 bp. Migration distance is logarithmically related to size, so interpolation between markers can estimate fragment size.

quizQuestions.question: Why is TAE buffer preferred over TBE when DNA will be extracted from the gel for cloning?
options: TAE provides better resolution for small fragments
TBE contains borate that can inhibit downstream enzymatic reactions
TAE is more expensive and therefore higher quality
TBE causes DNA to denature
quizQuestions.explanation: TBE (Tris-borate-EDTA) contains borate which can form complexes with DNA sugars and inhibit enzymes like ligase and restriction endonucleases. TAE (Tris-acetate-EDTA) does not have this problem, making it better for gel purification.

quizQuestions.question: What would you observe on a gel if your restriction digest had star activity?
options: No bands at all
Expected bands only
Unexpected additional bands from non-specific cutting
All bands would be the same size
quizQuestions.explanation: Star activity causes the enzyme to cut at sequences similar to its recognition site, producing additional unexpected bands. These extra bands represent fragments from non-canonical cut sites.

quizQuestions.question: How do restriction enzymes distinguish their own bacterial DNA from invading phage DNA?
options: Bacterial DNA has a different sequence than phage DNA
A companion methyltransferase adds methyl groups to recognition sites in bacterial DNA, protecting it
Restriction enzymes only work on single-stranded DNA
Bacterial DNA is stored in the nucleus where enzymes cannot access it
quizQuestions.explanation: In restriction-modification systems, the bacterial methyltransferase adds methyl groups to the same recognition sequences that the restriction enzyme cuts. The enzyme does not cut methylated sites, so bacterial DNA is protected while unmethylated phage DNA is destroyed.

quizQuestions.question: For a gel art lab, you want many small, closely spaced bands. Which strategy would work best?
options: Use an 8-base rare cutter enzyme on a small plasmid
Use a 4-base frequent cutter enzyme on a large plasmid or genomic DNA
Use a blunt-end cutter instead of a sticky-end cutter
Use no enzyme and run uncut DNA
quizQuestions.explanation: Four-base cutters recognize sites every ~256 bp on average, producing many small fragments. Using this on a large DNA substrate generates many bands. Eight-base cutters produce few large fragments, which would not create the desired dense banding pattern.

quizQuestions.question: Why does bromophenol blue in loading dye help monitor gel progress without visualizing DNA?
options: It binds to DNA and makes it glow
It migrates at a predictable rate (~300 bp in 1% gel), acting as a visible tracking marker
It increases the voltage across the gel
It denatures the DNA for better separation
quizQuestions.explanation: Bromophenol blue is a small colored molecule that migrates through the gel at approximately the same rate as a 300 bp DNA fragment (in 1% agarose). By watching the dye front, you can estimate when the gel has run long enough without stopping to visualize DNA.

quizQuestions.question: Match each troubleshooting symptom with its most likely cause:

pairs.term: Smeared bands instead of discrete bands
pairs.definition: DNA degradation from nuclease contamination or overloading
Forgot to add stain, or no DNA in sample
Excessive voltage causing uneven heating across the gel
Star activity from non-optimal digest conditions

quizQuestions.explanation: Each gel artifact has characteristic causes: smearing indicates degradation, invisible bands mean missing stain or DNA, curved bands result from heat gradients, and extra bands suggest star activity.

quizQuestions.question: Order the agarose concentrations from best for SMALL fragments to best for LARGE fragments:
quizQuestions.explanation: Higher agarose concentrations create smaller pores that better resolve small fragments. Lower concentrations have larger pores that allow large fragments to migrate and separate. 2.0% is best for small, 0.5% is best for large.

designChallenges.title: Gel Art Design Challenge
designChallenges.scenario: For the Week 2 Gel Art Lab, you want to create a visually striking banding pattern on an agarose gel. You have access to a 5 kb plasmid (with a known sequence/restriction map) and the following enzymes: EcoRI, HindIII, BamHI, KpnI, EcoRV, and SacI. Your goal is to create a specific artistic pattern with bands at defined positions.
tasks: Choose a plasmid (either use a real plasmid map from Addgene, or the example pUC19)
Design 3-4 different restriction digest combinations (single digests and double digests) that will create distinct, visually interesting banding patterns
Predict the fragment sizes for each digest using the plasmid sequence and restriction sites
Sketch the expected gel image: which lanes will have which bands? Plan the loading order to create a visual composition (e.g., a gradient from many small fragments to few large fragments)
Use Benchling or SnapGene to perform a virtual digest and compare your predictions to the software output
hints: A single restriction digest of a circular plasmid linearizes it (1 band). A double digest with 2 sites creates 2 fragments. Triple digest → 3 fragments, etc.
For visual interest, mix lanes with 1 band (uncut or single digest) with lanes containing 3-5 bands (multiple digests)
Fragment sizes should span the range well-separated by your gel (1% agarose separates 400-8000 bp well). Avoid all fragments being >5 kb or all <500 bp
Consider loading a DNA ladder in lane 1 for reference, then your artistic pattern in lanes 2-8. Symmetrical patterns or gradients work well visually
designChallenges.connection: This IS the Week 2 Gel Art Lab! Planning your digests ahead of time and predicting the results is how you create intentional gel art rather than random bands. Benchling virtual digest is a required homework tool.

designChallenges.title: Gel Troubleshooting Challenge
designChallenges.scenario: You ran an agarose gel but the results look wrong. Here are three problems you observe: (1) Lane 2 has smeared bands instead of sharp bands, (2) Lane 4 shows NO bands at all even though you loaded DNA, (3) Lane 6 has bands, but they're all much higher (larger) than expected based on your ladder.
tasks: Diagnose the cause of the smeared bands in lane 2. List at least 3 possible explanations.
Diagnose why lane 4 has no visible bands. List at least 3 possible explanations and how you'd test each one.
Diagnose why lane 6 bands are running larger than expected. What could cause DNA to migrate more slowly?
For each problem, propose a specific fix you would implement in your next gel run
hints: Smearing can be caused by: (1) Degraded DNA (from nuclease contamination or old sample), (2) Over-loading the well with too much DNA, (3) RNA contamination (RNase treatment can help), (4) running the gel too fast causing heating

No bands: (1) Forgot to add loading dye and DNA floated away, (2) DNA concentration too low to detect, (3) Loaded into the wrong end of the gel (loaded near the anode instead of cathode!), (4) Forgot to add ethidium bromide or SYBR Safe

Bands running larger: (1) Sample contains large protein or RNA contaminants, (2) Not fully digested (partial digest leaves large uncut fragments), (3) DNA is supercoiled (form I) which runs faster than expected, (4) Wrong agarose concentration

Fixes: For smearing, use fresh DNA, lower load amount, add RNase. For no bands, check loading orientation, increase DNA amount, verify stain. For size issues, treat with RNase, run digest longer, use relaxed/linear DNA
designChallenges.connection: Troubleshooting is a critical lab skill. Every molecular biologist has seen weird gel results and needs to diagnose the problem systematically. This prepares you for the real lab where gels don't always work perfectly the first time.

conceptConnections.relationship: Gel electrophoresis was the original separation method for Sanger sequencing, where DNA fragments terminating at each base were resolved by size on polyacrylamide gels. Modern capillary electrophoresis is an automated evolution of this principle.

After assembling synthetic DNA fragments (e.g., via Gibson Assembly), gel electrophoresis is used to verify the assembly by checking that the product is the expected size. Restriction digest followed by gel electrophoresis confirms that the synthetic construct has the correct structure.

Restriction enzymes cut DNA at specific sequences, and understanding the coding sequence within an expression cassette allows you to choose enzymes that cut outside the gene of interest for cloning into expression vectors.

homeworkConnections.relevance: Understanding restriction enzyme recognition sequences, cut sites, and the distinction between single and double digests is essential for performing virtual digests in Benchling. The enzyme table and sticky/blunt end concepts from this guide directly apply.

homeworkConnections.title: Part 2: Gel Art Lab
homeworkConnections.relevance: The hands-on gel art lab requires you to choose restriction enzymes, perform digests, run gels, and create artistic banding patterns. Every section of this guide, from casting and loading to visualization and troubleshooting, directly applies to the lab.
